This is an extremely important class and is currently being taught in a terrible fashion. Note that my response to this question is an overall evaluation of the course - both positive and negative. For better or for worse, this was the course I was most engaged with this semester, and as I had heard from prior students, I very much had a love-hate relationship with it. I definitely feel like I learned a lot, but I don't think my (or anyone's) grade in this course or the assignments is reflective of our knowledge. Questions in problem sets and exams were ambiguously and badly worded, so that the vast majority of our effort in these assessments was spent on not learning the material, but trying decipher what specifically was being asked for. And then if we presented a response or methodology that was not exactly what was expected, even with rigorous justification of our interpretation of a vague question, we would get points off. Exam questions were primarily not based around the fundamental concepts central to "Energy Systems Analysis", but mostly asked us simply to regurgitate obscure figures from random sections of lectures and readings (even those not explicitly assigned), and therefore tested us not on our knowledge but on which graphs we happened to bring in with our exam notes and how quickly we could find them. Arnulf is clearly an expert in the field and I really enjoyed his lecture style - I think there is a lot that students can gain from his knowledge and insights, but the assessments in the course (problem sets and exams) need work to actually be an accurate evaluation of our understanding of the material. The TFs, on the other hand, were less than helpful in responding to student questions, and often refused to elaborate or give any useful information even during the token "TF information sessions" (a few TF responses I'd received even turned out to be misleading and utterly time-wasting). They did not hold their assertion at the beginning of the course that our work in the problem sets would be judged primarily on the justification of our methodology, instead penalizing based on their interpretation of the vague questions and for being transparent about our process. Point deductions from TF grading often seemed to be completely arbitrary, and at times erroneous and nonsensical. This course definitely has a lot of value, and I have heard that one possible motivation behind all the ambiguity is to force us to really analyze complex questions from multiple angles and thereby gain a greater hold of the material. But the assessments are by no means an accurate representation of our understanding and grades seem arbitrary, and I don't believe this is appropriate for a graduate-level course.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?

This class is quite a bit of work (in terms of problem sets), but without this class I would have no understanding of the energy industry, even having taken very many undergraduate energy courses.

This course is well-known to many FES alumni in the energy space, just as Grubler is internationally. If you put in the extra effort to distinguish yourself from the group it will serve you well in the future.

I would also say supplement the lectures with the readings because they are very interesting and tie things together well.
